text: Applications
ACE 2-1

The following table shows typical weights for young tiger cubs from birth to 11 weeks. Use the data to answer ACE 1a–e.

a. At what age do tiger cubs typically weigh 7 kilograms?

b. Plot the (age, weight) data on a coordinate grid with appropriate scales. Explain why it does or does not make sense to connect the points on that graph.

c. How would you describe the pattern relating tiger cub age and weight?

d. How is the pattern shown in the data table?

e. How is the pattern shown in the coordinate graph?

a. Between 7 and 8 weeks.

b. It makes sense to connect points on a coordinate graph, because growth occurs all throughout each week.

c. The tiger cubs’ weight increases fairly steadily at a rate of about 0.75 kilograms per week. Students may have a hard time understanding that a “steady” rate may not be exact. The cub growing 0.7 kilograms one week and 0.8 kilograms the next, for example, would be considered “steady” even if the cub did not grow the exact same amount each week.

d. The rate of change is seen in the successive differences of weights from one week to the next in the table

e. The relatively steady growth rate shows up in the graph as a linear increasing pattern of data points. Students may say that the line goes up at the same level of “steepness” throughout the weeks.
ACE 2-2

Desi is planning a go-kart party. Kartland gives him a table of group rates. Thunder Alley gives him a graph. The table and graph are shown here.

a. Find the cost at both locations for 50 laps.

b. Find the cost at both locations for 20 laps.

c. Find the cost at both locations for 35 laps.

d. Look for patterns in the relationships between number of laps and cost at Kartland. How is the pattern shown in the table?

e. Look for patterns in the relationships between number of laps and cost at Thunder Alley. How is the pattern shown in the graph?

f. Which location seems to offer the better deal?

a. The cost for 50 laps is $105.00 at Kartland and about $95.00 at Thunder Alley.

b. The cost for 20 laps will cost $45.00 at Kartland and about $50.00 at Thunder Alley.

c. The cost for 35 laps will cost $75.00 at Kartland and about $70.00 at Thunder Alley.

d. It looks as if the pricing plan at Kartland is $5.00 for the group and then $2.00 per lap. The table shows an increase in cost of $20.00 for each 10 laps ($2.00 per lap), but the first 10 laps cost $25.00 (suggesting the $5.00 group fee).

e. At Thunder Alley, it looks like you pay $20.00 for the group and then about $1.50 per lap. You can see this on the graph because the first point is (0, 20), or 0 laps, but you’ve had to pay $20.00. It then increases at a steady rate after that. It is a steady slope of over 10 and up 15 (suggesting the per-lap charge of $1.50). The slope is clearest for the points (0, 20) and (40, 80), which shows that for 40 laps, the increase in cost is $60.00.

f. Answers will vary. The location with the better deal depends on how many laps. Kartland is cheaper than Thunder Alley if Desi and his friends want to go less than 30 laps (both charge $65.00 for 30 laps). Over 30 laps, the cost is cheaper at Thunder Alley.
ACE 2-3

The following table shows the fees charged for campsites at one of the campgrounds on the Ocean Bike Tours route.

a. Make a coordinate graph of the data.

b. Does it make sense to connect the points on the graph? Explain.

c. Using the table, describe the pattern of change in the total campground fee as the number of camp sites increases.

d. How is the pattern you described in ACE 3a shown in your graph?

b. It doesn’t make sense to connect the points because campers come in whole numbers only.

c. The camping fee appears to be $12.50 per campsite.

d. The fee rule is shown in the steady (linear) upward trend of points on the graph— an increase of 1 camper leads to an increase of $12.50 in total cost. It is not likely that students will describe the graph like this, though. Students will notice that the line increases at the same “steepness.” The distance between each of the points remains the same as well.
ACE 2-4

A camping supply store rents camping gear for $25 per person for a week.

a. Make a table of the total rental charges for 0, 5, 10, . . . , 40 campers.

b. Make a coordinate graph using the data in your table.

c. Compare the pattern in your table and graph with patterns you found in the campground fee data in ACE 3. Describe the similarities and differences between the two sets of data.

c. The pattern of change in the table and the graph is very similar to that of ACE 3. As the number of campers renting gear or the number of campsites (x-axis) increases, so does the cost (y-axis) and at a steady rate. The only difference is that the rate of change in camping gear cost is double the rate of change for campsite usage.
ACE 2-5

Some class officers want to sell T-shirts to raise funds for a class trip.

They ask the students in their class how much they would pay for a shirt and record the data in a table.

a. Describe the relationship between the price per shirt and the expected number of shirt sales. Is this the sort of pattern you would expect?

b. Copy and complete this table to show the relationship between price per shirt and the expected total value of the shirt sales.
a. It looks as if each increase of $5 in the price will lead to a loss of 10 shirt sales. As price increases, fewer people will be willing to pay for the shirts, so yes, this pattern is expected.

c. How would you describe the relationship between price per shirt and expected total value of shirt sales? Is this the sort of pattern you would expect?

d. Make coordinate graphs of the data like the ones shown here:

c. As price increases, the income increases to a maximum of $450 at a price of $15 per shirt; however, the projected income then begins to decrease because the loss of customers overcomes the gain from higher prices. Students might find this at first surprising but not unbelievable.
e. Explain how your answers to ACE 5a and 5c are shown in the graphs.
e. The first graph shows steady decline in sales as price increases; the second graph shows increase to a maximum and then decrease of income as price increases.
ACE 2-6

The bike tour partners need to rent a truck to transport camping gear, clothes, and bicycle repair equipment. They check prices at two truck rental companies.

a. East Coast Trucks charges $4.00 for each mile driven. Make a table of the charges for 0, 100, 200, . . . , 800 miles.

b. Philadelphia Truck Rental charges $200.00 per day and an additional $3.00 for each mile driven. Make a table of the charges for renting a truck for five days and driving it 0, 100, 200, . . . , 800 miles.

c. On one coordinate graph, plot the charges for both rental companies. Use different colors to mark points representing the two companies’ plans.

d. Based on your work in ACE 6a–c, which company offers the better deal? Explain.
d. The tables and graph show equal charges for 200 miles, with East Coast Trucks cheaper for fewer than 200 miles and Philadelphia Truck Rental cheaper thereafter.
ACE 2-7

The table that follows shows fees for using a campsite at a state park for 1 day up to the park limit of 10 days.

a. Make a coordinate graph representing data in the table.

b. Does it make sense to connect the points on your graph? Explain.

c. Describe the pattern relating the variables days of use and campsite fee.

b. Since camping fees appear to be charged by the whole day, it does not make sense to connect the dots in this graph.

c. It appears that there is a $10 registration fee, then $10 per day for the first 6 days and $5 per day thereafter.
Suppose a motion detector tracks the time and the distance traveled as you walk 40 feet in 8 seconds. The results are shown in the graphs that follow. Use them to answer ACE 8–9.
ACE 2-8
Match one of the (time, distance) graphs with the story (A, B, C, D, E) that describes each walk.

A.

You walk at a steady pace of 5 feet per second.

B.

You walk slowly at first and then steadily increase your

walking speed.

C.

You walk rapidly at first, pause for several seconds, and then walk at an increasing rate for the rest of the trip

D.

You walk at a steady rate for 3 seconds, pause for 2 seconds, and then walk at a steady rate for the rest of the trip.

E.

You walk rapidly at first but gradually slow down as you reach the end of the walk.

A - Graph 3

B - Graph 4

C - Graph 1

D - Graph 5

E - Graph 2
ACE 2-9
For each walk in the graphs in ACE 8, complete a (time, distance) table like the one below. Use numbers that will match the pattern in the graph.
ACE 2-10
The graphs that follow show five patterns for the daily sales of a new video game as time passed after its release. Match each (time, sales) graph with the story (A, B, C, D) it tells.

A.

The daily sales rose rapidly, then leveled off, and then declined rapidly.

B.

The daily sales rose at a steady rate.

C.

The daily sales dropped rapidly at first and then at a slower rate.

D.

Choose one of the graphs you did not select in ACE 10a–c. Write a story that the graph would say about the sales of a new video game as time passed after its release.

A - Graph 1

B - Graph 4

C - Graph 3

D - Graph 2: Answer should reflect that sales started out high and then decreased steadily until it was eventually zero. Graph 5: Sales started out at a certain amount and never changed.
Connections
ACE 2-11

The graph that follows shows how the temperature changed during an all-day hike by students in the Terrapin Middle School science club.

a. What was the maximum temperature, and when did it occur?

b. When was the temperature rising most rapidly?

c. When was the temperature falling most rapidly?

d. When was the temperature about 24°C?

e. The hikers encountered a thunderstorm with rain. When do you think this happened?

a. Maximum temperature of 30°C occurred at points 2, 2.5, and 3.5 hours into the hike.

b. Temperature seems to be rising most rapidly between 1 and 1.5 hours into the hike. It looks like the temperature rose from about 21°C to about 27°C within that half hour.

c. Temperature seems to be falling most rapidly between 3.5 and 4.0 hours into the hike. It appears to have decreased from 30°C to 18°C within that half hour.

d. Temperature was about 24°C at points about 1.25 and 3.75 hours into the hike.

e. The thunderstorm (and likely cooling of the temperature) probably occurred about 3.5 hours into the hike and lasted about half an hour.
ACE 2-12
Jacy works at an amusement park on the weekends. The graph shows parking costs at the parking lot that Jacy uses while he is at work.

a. Multiple Choice

How much will Jacy spend to park for less than half an hour?

A. $0.50

B. $0.75

C. $1.00

D. $1.50

b. Multiple Choice

How much will Jacy spend to park for 4 hours and 15 minutes?

A. $6.00

B. $6.50

C. $6.75

D. $7.00

a. C

b. C
ACE 2-13

The area of a rectangle is the product of its length and its width.

a. Find all whole-number pairs of length and width values that give an area of 24 square meters. Copy and extend the table to record the pairs.

b. Make a coordinate graph of the (length, width) data from ACE 13a.

c. Connect the points on your graph if it makes sense to do so. Explain your decision.

d. Describe the relationship between length and width for rectangles of area 24 square meters.

c. It makes sense to connect the points because rectangles can have any length and width with product 24 (e.g., 1.5 and 16).

d. As length increases, the corresponding width decreases rapidly at first and then more slowly to keep the constant product of 24. This is an example of an inverse variation relationship that students will encounter in future units. Such relationships have the algebraic standard form xy = k or y = k/x. This is helpful information for you as the teacher but not something to expect students to make sense of at this point.
ACE 2-14

The perimeter of any rectangle is the sum of its side lengths.

a. Make a table of all possible whole-number pairs of length and width values for a rectangle with a perimeter of 18 meters.

b. Make a coordinate graph of the (length, width) data from ACE 14a.

c. Connect the points on your graph if it makes sense to do so. Explain your decision.

d. Describe the relationship between length and width for rectangles of perimeter 18 meters. Explain how that relationship is shown in the table and graph.

c. It makes sense to connect the points on the graph because lengths and widths can be any parts of a meter (e.g., 3.5 and 5.5).

d. As length increases at a constant rate (add 1), the corresponding widths decrease at a constant rate (subtract 1). This is shown by the downward slope of the graph from left or right and by the patterns of change in the rows of the table.
ACE 2-15

Students plan to hold a car wash to raise money. The students ask some adults how much they would pay for a car wash. The table that follows shows the results of the research.

a. Make a coordinate graph of the (price, customers) data.

b. Describe the pattern relating the price to the number of customers. Explain how the table and the graph show the pattern.

c. Based on the pattern, what number of customers would you predict if the price were $16? If the price were $20? If the price were $2?

b. As price increases at a constant rate, the number of customers decreases at a constant rate of about 7.5 customers per dollar increase in price.

c. Based on the pattern, you would predict 30 customers if the price were $16, 0 customers if the price were $20, and 135 customers if the price were $2.
ACE 2-16

The table that follows shows the winning countries and the winning times for the women’s Olympic 400-meter dash since 1964.

Make a coordinate graph of the (year, time) information. Choose a scale that allows you to see the differences between the winning times.

As time passes from 1964 to 1980, the times for the 400-meter dash decreased quickly. Between 1980 and 1992, the times stayed about the same. After a large decrease between 1992 and 1996, the time increased by a large amount at first, then just gradually until 2012. Overall, the times appear to be falling. In 1996, the best time was earned (48.25 seconds).
ACE 2-17

Here are the box-office earnings for a movie during each of the first eight weeks following its release.

a. Make a coordinate graph showing the data from the table.

b. Explain how the weekly earnings changed as time passed. How is this pattern of change shown in the table and the graph? Why might this change have occurred?

c. What were the total earnings of the movie in the eighth week?

d. Make a coordinate graph showing the total earnings after each week.

e. Explain how the movie’s total earnings changed over time. How is this pattern of change shown in the table and the graph? Why might this change have occurred?

b. After a fairly successful opening week, interest in the movie peaked in the second week and then began to decline (probably as the potential customers all saw the film). The decline is a bit more rapid in weeks 3−6. In the table, you see the weekly earnings decreasing after the peak in week 2. In the graph, you see the points going down to the right after week 2.

c. Total earnings in the eight weeks for which data are given were $83 million. Students may miss that the weekly earnings will have to be totaled over time.

d. See graph below

e. The cumulative earnings increase rapidly at first and then more slowly as the film’s audience is tapped out. This pattern is shown by the rapid rise of the data points at first and then a slower rise from week to week for the later points.
ACE 2-18

Two students were thinking about the relationship between price and number of T-shirt sales in a school fundraiser. They had different ideas about independent and dependent variables.

Shane argued that changing the price would change the number sold, so price is the independent variable. Victoria argued that the goal for number sold would dictate the price to be charged, so number of sales is the independent variable.

What do you think of these two ideas? Does it always matter which variable is considered independent and which dependent?

In fact, the choice of variable to be labeled independent and that to be labeled dependent is often (but not always in applications) arbitrary. It depends on the way the person framing the problem views the variables. Both of these arguments are reasonable.
Extensions
ACE 2-19
Use what you know about decimals to find coordinates of five points that lie on the line segment between the labeled points on each of these graphs:
ACE 2-20

Each of these graphs shows a relationship between independent (x-axis) and dependent (y-axis) variables. However, the scales on the coordinate axes are not the same for all the graphs.

a. For each graph, complete this statement:

The graph shows that y increases by ___ for every increase of 1 in x.

b. Which graph shows the dependent variable increasing most rapidly as the independent variable increases?

c. Which graph shows the dependent variable increasing most slowly as the independent variable increases?

a. Graph 1 shows that y increases by 2 for every increase of 1 in x.

Graph 2 shows that y increases by 1.5 for every increase of 1 in x.

Graph 3 shows that y increases by about 0.75 for every increase of 1 in x.

Graph 4 shows that y increases by 1 for every increase of 1 in x.

b. Graph 1 shows the greatest rate of increase in the dependent variable (2 up for each 1 over). While Graph 4 looks equally steep, the dependent variable increases only from 0 to 5 over the interval shown.

c. While Graphs 2 and 3 seem to have the same slope, the scales on the y-axis are different. So Graph 3 shows a pattern of slower increase in the dependent variable over the interval shown. Graph 2 shows that y increases by 1.5 for every increase of 1 in x. Graph 3 shows that y increases by about 0.75 for every increase of 1 in x.
ACE 2-21

a. Copy and complete the following table relating car wash price to projected income.

b. Make a coordinate graph of the (price, income) data.

c. Explain why it makes sense to consider price the independent variable and income the dependent variable.

d. Describe the way a projected car wash income changes as the price increases. Explain how this pattern is shown in the graph.

e. Suppose the students must pay $1.50 per car for water and cleaning supplies. How can you use this factor to find the profit from the car wash for various prices?

c. It makes sense to consider price to be the independent variable because that is the quantity that the car wash operators can manipulate as they choose in this situation. The number of customers will be determined by how the price is set.

d. As the price increases from a low value, the income increases to a maximum value of $750 at the $10 price, and the income decreases as the price increases further. This happens because a higher price reduces the number of customers.

e. To calculate profit when the $1.50 cost per car is considered, one has to deduct that number from the price per customer before multiplying to get a total. For instance, a per-car price of $4.00 would yield 120 customers and income of $480.00. However, only $2.50 of that price would be profit, so the projected profit at a price of $4.00 per car would actually be $2.50 × 120, or $300.00.

dataSet.name: Price Students Are Willing to Pay for Shirt
Price Customers Are Willing to Pay for a Car Wash
Rectangles with Area 24 Square Meters Answer
